urn:contentItem:4P8B-RBN0-TXN5-S08V-00000-00BRIEFS2000-05-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:16ZLexisNexisNEWSIn Brief OverseasPg. 11BRIEFSWORLD

Milosevic ally shot at country fair

BELGRADE. In yet another sign of the lethal atmosphere in postwar Yugoslavia, a senior member of Serbia's ruling Socialist Party was shot dead at a farmers' fair on Saturday. It was the fourth assassination of a close ally of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic this year. Bosko Perosevic was shot in the head at point-blank range in the city of Novi Sad. Police arrested Milivoje Gutovic, 50, a security guard at the fair who was born in Mr Perosevic's village of Ratkovo.

Ethiopia claims wins in border war

ADDIS ABABA. Ethiopia claimed dramatic battlefield victories against Eritrea yesterday as fighting raged along their disputed border for a second day, despite international appeals for peace. The government said Ethiopian troops had destroyed eight Eritrean army divisions while sweeping across lines of enemy trenches near the Badme region of their disputed border. The UN Security Council is expected to meet today, with Britain and the US to call for an arms embargo against Ethiopia and Eritrea.

Forest fire damage bill tops $1 billion

LOS ALAMOS. An army of 1000 firefighters on the ground and in the sky struggled on Saturday to contain a wind-driven forest fire that forced thousands of people from their homes, caused $US1 billion ($A1.7 billion) in damages and charred vast areas at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, the top US nuclear research facility. The mighty blaze spread across more than 14,596 hectares of scenic northern New Mexico.

Bus crash kills 43 Muslim pilgrims

KAKANJ, BOSNIA. Forty-three people were killed when a bus carrying Muslim pilgrims plunged 20 metres into a river in central Bosnia early on Saturday, authorities said. The bus broke through a bridge fence on a highway and fell into the Bosnia river near the town of Kakanj, 50 kilometres north-west of Sarajevo, investigative judge Bakir Ljubovic said.

Ducks ruffle House of Commons

LONDON. A family of ducks caused a major flap at London's House of Commons on Saturday when they plummeted 25 metres down a underground railway ventilation shaft. Security was ruffled when the mother duck sneaked through gates into parliament's courtyard with her seven ducklings in tow. But as they crossed a Tube ventilation grille, her brood suddenly slipped through the holes. Apparently ducks have been living in the House of Commons for 20 years.

urn:contentItem:5F11-V2N1-JCMN-Y2K7-00000-002014 Is Australia's Third Warmest Year On Record, BOM Confirms2015-01-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:16ZLexisNexis2014 Is Australia's Third Warmest Year On Record, BOM ConfirmsAthena Yenko

Jan 06, 2015 (International Business Times Australia:http://au.ibtimes.com Delivered by Newstex)
The year 2014 was Australia's third-warmest year on record since the Bureau of Meteorology or BOM conducted its temperature observations nationwide in 1910. The annual national mean temperature was +0.91 degree Celsius above average, according to data collected and analysed by BOM.


Seven of Australia's ten warmest years on record have occurred in the 13 years from 2002, with 2011 as the one-cooler-than-average year in the past decade. The 10-year mean temperature for 2005-2014 was 0.55 degree Celsius above average and the highest in record, BOM said.
Southern and western Queensland and most of Western Australia experienced annual mean temperatures for the duration of 2014. For Southern Australia as a whole or the area south of the Northern territory border, the annual mean temperature was the second-highest on record with an anomaly of +1.28 degree Celsius, behind +1.29 degree Celsius recorded in 2013.
Heatwaves and warm spells were experienced from late Dec 2013 to early Jan 2014 by people residing in central and eastern Australia while people in the southeast Australia experienced heatwaves and warm spells in mid-January to the second half of May; South Australia, New South Wales and Southern Queensland in late October. Central Australia, New South Wales, southern Queensland and Northern Territory particularly affected by two heat waves from mid to end of November.
Subsequently, Australia experienced bushfires that claimed significant loss. The Bushfire on Perth Hills on Jan 12 for example saw a total loss of 56 residential dwellings across Parkerville, Stone Ville, Hovea and Mount Helena. The bushfires that occurred in Grampians National Park on Jan 15 claimed the lives of 7000 stock animals and destroyed 30 residential dwellings.
East Gippsland experienced a number of fires between Jan 28 to Feb 26, burning an estimated 210000 hectares of land. Fires had also burnt a total of 425000 hectares of land and 12 houses in the Flinders Ranges, Murraylands and southern Barossa Valley between Jan 14 to Jan 17; while 5 houses were destroyed by fires by the Murraguldrie State Forest fire.
Australia's humid temperature seemed to be unstoppable. On the second day of January of 2015, BOM had forecasted a widespread heatwave with temperatures in the high-30s and low-40s across southern Australian. "Fire Danger ratings are in the Severe to Extreme range across several states, with some areas of catastrophic in South Australia," BOM said in its announcement at the time.
Read More of BOM's Annual Climate Statement of 2014.[1]

urn:contentItem:53HV-J871-JD3N-53KF-00000-00RESEARCH NEWS2011-08-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 34RESEARCH NEWS

FIRE MYTHS UP IN SMOKE

This summer, forest fires swept through parts of Arizona and New Mexico, scorching property and vast expanses of ecosystems and resulting in the evacuation of the enormous Los Alamos National Laboratory.

Many fear that more extreme weather may mean bushfires will only become more common in coming years. So what can we do about it?

Last week, scientists at the Pacific Wildland Fire Sciences Laboratory in Seattle, Washington, set out to answer that question and to smoke out some common myths about forest fires, and their control and prevention.

They found that in 98 per cent of cases the fires quietly burn out and go largely unnoticed by the public, said fire and environment researcher David Peterson.

Small fires seldom make the news or draw much scientific interest. But it's these fires that unexpected weather can amplify until they become massive wildfires that need thousands of fire fighters and dozens of air tanker planes to control.

And while there's no question that wildfire fighters and smoke jumpers make a huge difference in controlling fires, when it comes to actually dousing the flames, the researchers explained that it's really up to the elements. ``Suppressing'' a big wildfire is only really effective to guide its path until rain finally snuffs it out. A more effective method for fighting wildfires is to treat fire-prone land before a blaze begins, they argued.

As to the question of climate change, ongoing research is hinting at a link between hot and dry, and cool and wet spells, with the location and severity of big forest fire breakouts.

NEW SCIENTIST

urn:contentItem:5KXJ-6NH1-JD3N-54T6-00000-00OUR NATURAL DISASTER PLANS ARE A DISASTER2016-10-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:16ZLexisNexisOPEDPg. 24OUR NATURAL DISASTER PLANS ARE A DISASTERJUDY SLATTER

It's time to rethink disaster management. We spend too much on meeting needs today and nowhere near enough on saving lives tomorrow. No matter where we live, disasters affect us all. Even as we're cleaning up the debris from howling wind storms and sudden floods in our own backyards, many Australians have been spared the worst.

On our TVs, we have been seeing tragic images of Hurricane Matthew's fury. In Haiti, Cuba and the United States, thousands are in mourning after losing loved ones in the wake of the hurricane.

According to the Red Cross World Disasters Report 2016, released today, disasters killed 32,550 people in 2015, affected 108 million more and cost the world $92.5 billion.

As a global community, we don't cope with disasters very well. We spend too much on clean-up and recovery because we spend nowhere near enough on prevention or mitigation.

Last year's natural disasters cost Australia at least $9 billion, according to the Australian Business Roundtable for Disaster Resilience and Safer Communities. That's expected to double by 2030. Yet we spent barely $50 million to prepare for these disasters. This trend is reflected around the world. The World Disasters Report states one out of eight dollars allocated to disaster management is spent on reducing and preventing risks. This makes no sense as global economic losses from disasters soar.

Let's rebalance our budgets to prevent needs tomorrow -instead of just meeting needs today. This won't just keep costs down. It will save lives, prevent needless suffering, protect economies, maintain livelihoods and keep people out of poverty.

The World Disasters Report argues that investing in resilience is the best way to save lives and money.

"Resilience" refers to how people adapt to, cope with and recover from adversity. It can be as personal as a family emergency plan, or as large-scale as a citywide approach to building.

It includes building flood levees or forest fire management but goes further to -encompass public health, community education, psychological wellbeing, economic stability and recovery.

The evidence is stacking up that it's a wise investment, whatever form it takes. We've just seen how pre-emptive evacuations in the United States helped keep the death toll down when Hurricane Matthew hit. It's time to ramp up our efforts in Australia. In line with the Productivity Commission's 2015 report, -Australian Red Cross is calling for a significant national -increase in investment in disaster risk reduction and community resilience.

Last week Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull said: "We need to spend more in advance so that we have to spend less after the rainfall events or the bushfire events that occur so it's important to invest in mitigation, in advance." We're asking all levels of government to prioritise disaster mitigation. Preparing for a flood, fire or hazard should be embedded in our culture, as commonplace as wearing a seat belt in a car. Our overseas aid program needs a similar approach, because disasters set back sustainable -development.

We could invest much more in practical ways to protect lives, homes and families.

Most importantly, we need locally generated ideas to make communities safer and better able to cope with adversity.

Natural disasters are -increasing in scale and frequency, compounded by a changing climate.

Without smarter ways to -reduce risk, they'll soon cost far more than our country can bear. Let's invest, today, in a safer future for tomorrow.

Judy Slatyer is CEO of Australian Red Cross

urn:contentItem:7V4P-M151-2RYX-1121-00000-00Firefighters prepare for worst2009-03-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Firefighters prepare for worstStephen McMahon and John Ferguson

VICTORIA BRACES

VICTORIANS must prepare for the worst today with galeforce winds up to 150km/h threatening to spark deathly firestorms, Premier John Brumby has warned.

He said the state's resilience and bravery would be tested over the next 24 hours.

Mr Brumby said ``savage windstorms'' could fan bushfires and spark new infernos.

More than 5000 firefighters have been mobilised to protect the state from fire conditions almost as bad as Black Saturday, when 210 people died.

They are concentrating on blazes in the Yarra Ranges, Gippsland and Wilsons Promontory that have been burning for three weeks.

Although temperatures have been downgraded to the mid-30s, wind gusts are expected to rip through areas already ravaged by fire.

A total fire ban has been declared and hundreds of schools will be closed.

Police arranged for text messages warning of the extreme weather conditions to be sent to five million mobile phones.

Thousands of residents in the Yarra Ranges left their homes yesterday after living on edge since February 7.

Towns at most risk include Warburton, Woods Point, Jamieson, Eildon and Mt Buller.

Authorities last night evacuated 45 residents from an aged care facility in Warburton amid concerns about their safety.

A fleet of ambulances took them to facilities in Croydon, Lilydale and Mount Waverley.

About 200 residents attended a meeting in the Warburton Town Hall, where they were told to exercise their fire plans. Many children were still in the town despite the fire threat.

Just two weeks after moving into their new home, the Devaus family packed their car and fled their East Warburton home again last night, the third time in a week.

Each time they leave, they take photos, spare clothes and a few special toys, fearing their home will be lost to the blaze that borders their town.

For Neil Devaus, a single-father of three, his children's safety is paramount.

``It's all part of being a father,'' he said.

``The kids' safety is the most important thing. I'd probably stay and defend if it wasn't for them, but I'm just not willing to put them at that risk.''

Mr Devaus said children Sherryn, 8, Lucas, 6, and Shaynaa, 5, found it exciting.

``The kids are treating it more as an adventure. They are aware there is a fire, but they don't really understand the danger. That's probably for the best.''

Emergency Services Commissioner Bruce Esplin said the warnings were not a case of ``crying wolf''.

``This is a very genuine concern about the weather tonight and tomorrow,'' he said.

Mr Esplin said the biggest danger would come with a volatile change in conditions, expected late today.

Metropolitan areas were also at risk, he said. The winds could cause blackouts, with fallen trees and other debris creating road hazards.

Kyneton races have been called off and Royal Botanic Gardens have been closed for fear of falling branches.

Mr Brumby called on Victorians to watch for arsonists.

``Arson is a despicable crime,'' he said.

``And I issue this warning: anyone who deliberately lights a fire will be caught and will feel the full force of the law.''

The fire threat is being described by the CFA as "ultra extreme". The forest fire danger index on Black Saturday was ranked 150 before the fires hit. Anything above 50 is considered extreme.

urn:contentItem:7WVW-6TW1-2PW5-F2MV-00000-00Qld: Twenty fires keep Queensland crews busy2009-10-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:16ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSQld: Twenty fires keep Queensland crews busyBRISBANE Oct 15

  Queensland firefighters are battling at least 20 fires across the state.
   Firefighting helicopters were called to water-bomb a large grass fire in the Lockyer Valley, west of Brisbane.


   Five urban and four rural fire crews responded to the fire which burnt out a square kilometre of grassland.
   The fire is now under control.
   At Toorbul, north of Brisbane, around 6ha of forestry has been burnt out and four crews are battling to bring the blaze under control.
   One fire crew continues to monitor a fire at Mountain View Drive at Minden, which caused problems on Wednesday.
   The fire was contained around midnight following water bombing by helicopters and the efforts of firefighters.
   In the Gold Coast hinterland, fires are burning at Parkwood and Pacific Pines, while to the west of Brisbane, a bulldozer is helping to contain a fire at Grandchester.
   Seven fire crews remain at a forest fire burning in inaccessible areas near Kilkivan, northwest of Brisbane, while six crew monitor a blaze at Granville.
   In central Queensland, crews are working on establishing containment lines and fire breaks around a fire at Mt Archer, near Rockhampton.
   The fire has been burning since Friday and authorities are urging residents with properties that back onto bushland in the Archer Ranges to be ready to enact their fire plan if necessary.
   In far north Queensland, blazes are burning at Little Mulgrave and Paddys Green, near Mareeba.

urn:contentItem:5CJM-GFN1-F03R-N3PN-00000-00Prince Harry Fixed Family's TV in Time for Brazil v Chile Match In The World Cup2014-07-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:16ZLexisNexisPrince Harry Fixed Family's TV in Time for Brazil v Chile Match In The World CupTanya Diente

Jul 01, 2014 (International Business Times Australia:http://au.ibtimes.com Delivered by Newstex)
On a visit to Chile, at a slum outside the former capital, Valparaiso, Prince Harry showed his practical side by fixing a family's TV just in time for them to watch their country beat Brazil in the World Cup.


According to Express, Prince Harry was in the village of El Vergel in Chile to see how the community is being rebuilt after a forest fire in April destroyed nine out of ten of the self-made homes. He was with the charity group Techo, who is assisting the villagers build new shelters made from clipboard and corrugated iron. Inside one of these shelters is Cocoa Perez, 50, and her teenage son and daughter.
Prince Harry noticed that their television was not working properly so according to Perez, he "looked at it and he started to fiddle with the cable."
Prince Harry managed to fix the television so the family could watch the Brazil v Chile match in the World Cup.
"Now I can tell everyone that Prince Harry is my TV repair man," Perez said after.
Outside, the prince was told that Techo had reinstated electricity. Access to sanitation was also regained with the installed portable toilets and communal water tanks.
Prince Harry told Mrs. Perez that "the worst seems to be over and now it's just a case of waiting," to which Perez replied "We just have to wait and be patient. We have no choice."
According to telegraph, another resident, Carolina Guzman, also talked to the prince for 10 minutes, where she recalled the day the fire consumed their home.
Guzman said she felt really moved, happy and thankful to have met Prince Harry that she felt like crying.
Later, Prince Harry visited the 11th Fire Company, established by the British immigrants in Valparaiso, where he met volunteer firefighter Gonzalo Alvarez.
Alvarez also lost his home to the fire yet on that day continued on driving the firetruck to help the other victims.
Alvarez said Prince Harry was surprised to learn that volunteers have to pay a small fee in order to volunteer, yet they are not given any salary.
"He was also very surprised to see people living up in the hills in tents when it is so cold," he said.

Metropolitan areas were also at risk, he said. The winds could cause blackouts, with fallen trees and other debris creating road hazards.

Kyneton races have been called off and Royal Botanic Gardens have been closed for fear of falling branches.

Mr Brumby called on Victorians to watch for arsonists.

``Arson is a despicable crime,'' he said.

``And I issue this warning: anyone who deliberately lights a fire will be caught and will feel the full force of the law.''

urn:contentItem:5KTX-BG81-F031-X4DM-00000-00Department says changes reduce risk of planned burns spreading out of control2016-09-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:16ZLexisNexisDepartment says changes reduce risk of planned burns spreading out of controlDavid Sparkes

Victorian authorities say a final report on the planned burn that spread out of control in Lancefield last year will influence how it conducts burns in the future.

The burn in Lancefield in September 2015 jumped containment lines and destroyed four homes.

The Inspector-General for Emergency Management released the final report on Wednesday and the Environment Department's deputy secretary for forest, fire and regions Lee Miezis said 19 of the 22 recommendations had already been implemented.

He said community input was an important part of the investigation.

"It was really important that the local community had confidence in the process that we went through to really understand what went wrong with that planned burning and make recommendations about how we can do better going forward," he said.

Mr Miezis repeated the department's previous admission that it had failed to adequately assess the risks of conducting a burn at the time, given the very dry conditions.

He said discussing the strategy with community members may have led to a more informed decision.

"That's been a critical thing for us and we have gone through and developed a community charter, which talks to how we are going to better involve communities, speak with communities, listen to communities and let them have a much stronger say in how we go about reducing bushfire risk," he said.

The department has also acted on recommendations it improve its risk assessment processes.

"We really need to make sure that at every level, we are understanding and assessing risk," he said.

"[That's] risk operationally in terms of how and when we conduct planned burns, the risk in how we are going about planning our planned burns.

"We've put new risk management processes in place, new approvals processes in place.

"We are training all our staff in risk management, so we have made a number of really key changes that really build on the independent investigation and its findings."

Botched fire burns for days

The department began the burn on September 30, 2015 at the Lancefield-Cobaw Croziers Track in the Macedon Ranges.

The fire breached containment lines three days later and burned for a further 10 days.

It burnt 3,000 hectares, destroying homes, sheds and fencing.

The Lancefield community was outraged after the burn went wrong, with many expressing disgust the burn had gone ahead at a time when conditions were extremely dry.

An Investigation Report was released five weeks later, identifying mistakes made and listing the 22 recommendations.

Yesterday's Final Progress Report outlined what the department had done so far to implement the recommendations and which still needed to be completed.

The department says it will implement the remaining three recommendations.

Mr Miezis was with Environment Minister Lily D'Ambrosio on Wednesday when she visited Lancefield to discuss progress on the changes with community representatives behind closed doors.

The Victorian Government had already apologised for the botched burn, but Ms D'Ambrosio repeated the promise to engage the community in decision-making in the future.

"Nothing will ever make up for the fact that a planned burn got out of control," she said.

"What we have learnt is that there are ways that we can plan these fuel reduction steps in a better way, [ways] that will reduce the risks of this happening again."

Cash for sports facilities

The minister also used the Lancefield trip to announce $800,000 worth of grants to upgrade recreational facilities in the town, which were part of a process to "rebuild trust" with the community following the botched burn.

The seven projects at Lancefield Park include enhancing netball and tennis courts, the main oval, cricket clubrooms, playground and bowls club.

A skate park, BMX track will also be installed and a new tractor provided.

urn:contentItem:5KRN-7FT1-JBJ7-N0S2-00000-00Toxic haze from Indonesian forest fires may have caused 100,000 deaths: report2016-09-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:16ZLexisNexisToxic haze from Indonesian forest fires may have caused 100,000 deaths: reportJewel Topsfield

Killer haze from forest fires that raged across Indonesia last year may have caused more than 100,000 premature deaths in Indonesia, Singapore and Malaysia, according to a new report that suggests a drastically higher death toll than Indonesian government figures.Harvard and Columbia University researchers used air pollution readings to calculate exposure to the deadly smoke."We estimate that haze in 2015 resulted in 100,300 excess deaths across Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore," says the report, which was published in Environmental Research Letters journal on September 19.It says this is more than double the estimated number of deaths as a result of haze in 2006, with much of the increase due to fires in Indonesia's South Sumatra province."Exposure to air pollution increases the risk of death from a number of ailments including stroke and respiratory illnesses," one of the researchers from Harvard University, Dr Shannon Koplitz, told Fairfax Media.Indonesians were the worst affected with an estimated 91,600 excess deaths.However Indonesia's disaster agency said just 24 people had died due to the 2015 fires, 12 of whom were killed fighting the fires and 12 from respiratory problems as a result of the haze."There is nothing like that (91,000 premature deaths)," Sutopo Purwo Nugroho from the National Disaster Management Agency (BNPB) told Fairfax Media."It is not true. The data is not valid. If there were high numbers of people dead we would have stated it in our almost daily forest fire press releases last year."Last year the agency estimated that 43 million Indonesians were exposed to the smog in Sumatra and Kalimantan alone and there were half a million cases of respiratory tract infections.Forest fires are an annual event in Indonesia, caused in part by "slash and burn" agriculture techniques, where farmers light fires to quickly and cheaply clear land.Last year's dry conditions, exacerbated by the El Nino effect, resulted in the worst haze in the region since 1997.Six Indonesian provinces declared a state of emergency, schools were closed in Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia, flights were grounded and warships were put on standby to evacuate people from the toxic haze.The fires strained relations between Indonesia and Singapore, where air pollution levels also skyrocketed."Indonesia's fires are probably the biggest global environmental disaster of the 21st century," Erik Meijaard, an Indonesian-based honorary associate professor at the University of Queensland wrote in

The Jakarta Globe last year.GreenpeaceIndonesia forest campaigner Yuyun Indradi said on Monday that now the scale of the death toll was known, failure to act immediately would be a crime."Now fires are back again," he said. "Industry and government must take real action to stop forest clearing and peatland drainage for plantations."Forestry and Environmental Ministry spokesman Novrizal told Fairfax MediaIndonesia had done many things to prevent last year's haze crisis.These included an education campaign about the danger of burning to clear land and a crackdown on companies found guilty of setting fires."A civil court sentenced a company to pay compensation of about one trillion rupiah," he said."We do joint patrols, with the TNI (military), police, forestry ministry and local people in all areas."He said this had resulted in a decrease of hotspots around Indonesia by 82 per cent in 2016 compared to the same period last year.The Harvard and Columbia university researchers developed a tool to help governments identify which fires have the highest potential to cause damage to human health."Our goal with this work is to provide a tool that can help stakeholders make evidence-based decisions related to fire and land use strategies, even as extreme haze events are unfolding," Dr Koplitz told Fairfax Media.   Follow Jewel Topsfield on Facebook

urn:contentItem:5KRN-T471-JD34-V3P0-00000-00Toxic haze may have killed 100,0002016-09-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10Toxic haze may have killed 100,000Indonesian forest fires Report reveals higher death toll that estimatedJewel Topsfield Herald Correspondent Indonesia

Killer haze from forest fires that raged across Indonesia last year may have caused more than 100,000 premature deaths in Indonesia, Singapore and Malaysia, according to a new report that suggests a drastically higher death toll than Indonesian government estimates.

Harvard and Columbia University researchers used air pollution readings to calculate exposure to the deadly smoke.

"We estimate that haze in 2015 resulted in 100,300 excess deaths across Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore," says the report, which was published in Environmental Research Letters journal on September 19.

It says this is more than double the estimated number of deaths as a result of haze in 2006, with much of the increase due to fires in Indonesia's South Sumatra province.

"Exposure to air pollution increases the risk of death from a number of ailments including stroke and respiratory illnesses," one of the researchers from Harvard University, Dr Shannon Koplitz, said. Indonesians were the worst affected with an estimated 91,600 excess deaths.

However Indonesia's disaster agency said just 24 people had died due to the 2015 fires, 12 of whom were killed fighting the fires and 12 from respiratory problems as a result of the haze.

"There is nothing like that (91,000 premature deaths)," Sutopo Purwo Nugroho from the National Disaster Management Agency (BNPB) said.

"It is not true. The data is not valid. If there were high numbers of people dead we would have stated it in our almost daily forest fire press releases last year."

Last year the agency estimated that 43 million Indonesians were exposed to the smog in Sumatra and Kalimantan alone and there were half a million cases of respiratory tract infections.

Forest fires are an annual event in Indonesia, caused in part by "slash and burn" agriculture techniques, where farmers light fires to quickly and cheaply clear land.

Last year's dry conditions, exacerbated by the El Nino effect, resulted in the worst haze in the region since 1997.

Six Indonesian provinces declared a state of emergency, schools were closed in Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia, flights were grounded and warships were put on standby to evacuate people from the toxic haze. The fires strained relations between Indonesia and Singapore, where air pollution levels also skyrocketed.

"Indonesia's fires are probably the biggest global environmental disaster of the 21st century," Erik Meijaard, an Indonesian-backed honorary associate professor at the University of Queensland wrote in The Jakarta Globe last year.

Greenpeace Indonesia forest campaigner Yuyun Indradi said on Monday that now the scale of the death toll was known, failure to act would be a crime. "Now fires are back again," he said. "Industry and government must take real action to stop forest clearing and peatland drainage for plantations."

Forestry and Environmental Ministry spokesman Novrizal told Fairfax Media Indonesia had done many things to prevent last year's haze crisis.

These included an education campaign about the danger of burning to clear land and a crackdown on companies found guilty of setting fires.

"A civil court sentenced a company to pay compensation of about one trillion rupiah," he said.

"We do joint patrols, with the TNI (military), police, forestry ministry and local people in all areas."

He said this had resulted in a decrease of hotspots around Indonesia by 82 per cent in 2016 compared to the same period last year.

The Harvard and Columbia university researchers developed a tool to help governments identify which fires have the highest potential to cause damage to human health.

A firefighter battles a blaze in Indonesia. Photo: Getty

urn:contentItem:5KRN-6TT1-JD34-V2FV-00000-00Toxic haze may have killed 100,0002016-09-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10Toxic haze may have killed 100,000Indonesian forest fires - Report reveals higher death toll than estimatedJewel Topsfield, Herald Correspondent, Indonesia

Killer haze from forest fires that raged across Indonesia last year may have caused more than 100,000 premature deaths in Indonesia, Singapore and Malaysia, according to a new report that suggests a drastically higher death toll than Indonesian government estimates.

Harvard and Columbia University researchers used air pollution readings to calculate exposure to the deadly smoke.

"We estimate that haze in 2015 resulted in 100,300 excess deaths across Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore," says the report, which was published in Environmental Research Letters journal on September 19.

It says this is more than double the estimated number of deaths as a result of haze in 2006, with much of the increase due to fires in Indonesia's South Sumatra province.

"Exposure to air pollution increases the risk of death from a number of ailments including stroke and respiratory illnesses," one of the researchers from Harvard University, Dr Shannon Koplitz, said. Indonesians were the worst affected with an estimated 91,600 excess deaths.

However Indonesia's disaster agency said just 24 people had died due to the 2015 fires, 12 of whom were killed fighting the fires and 12 from respiratory problems as a result of the haze.

"There is nothing like that (91,000 premature deaths)," Sutopo Purwo Nugroho from the National Disaster Management Agency (BNPB) said.

"It is not true. The data is not valid. If there were high numbers of people dead we would have stated it in our almost daily forest fire press releases last year."

Last year the agency estimated that 43 million Indonesians were exposed to the smog in Sumatra and Kalimantan alone and there were half a million cases of respiratory tract infections.

Forest fires are an annual event in Indonesia, caused in part by "slash and burn" agriculture techniques, where farmers light fires to quickly and cheaply clear land.

Last year's dry conditions, exacerbated by the El Nino effect, resulted in the worst haze in the region since 1997.

Six Indonesian provinces declared a state of emergency, schools were closed in Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia, flights were grounded and warships were put on standby to evacuate people from the toxic haze. The fires strained relations between Indonesia and Singapore, where air pollution levels also skyrocketed.

"Indonesia's fires are probably the biggest global environmental disaster of the 21st century," Erik Meijaard, an Indonesian-backed honorary associate professor at the University of Queensland wrote in The Jakarta Globe last year.

Greenpeace Indonesia forest campaigner Yuyun Indradi said on Monday that now the scale of the death toll was known, failure to act would be a crime. "Now fires are back again," he said. "Industry and government must take real action to stop forest clearing and peatland drainage for plantations."

Forestry and Environmental Ministry spokesman Novrizal told Fairfax Media Indonesia had done many things to prevent last year's haze crisis.

These included an education campaign about the danger of burning to clear land and a crackdown on companies found guilty of setting fires.

"A civil court sentenced a company to pay compensation of about one trillion rupiah," he said.

"We do joint patrols, with the TNI (military), police, forestry ministry and local people in all areas."

He said this had resulted in a decrease of hotspots around Indonesia by 82 per cent in 2016 compared to the same period last year.

The Harvard and Columbia university researchers developed a tool to help governments identify which fires have the highest potential to cause damage to human health.

urn:contentItem:5J27-7VX1-DY19-C4RR-00000-00Australian bushfires on the rise, new research finds2016-02-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:16ZLexisNexisAustralian bushfires on the rise, new research findsTom Arup, Environment Editor

The number of bushfires in Australia is on the rise - up 40 per cent since 2007 - local scientists have found.

In a new research paper, published on Wednesday in the journal Royal Society Open Science, scientists from CSIRO and University of Tasmania also say the increasing bushfire frequency indicates a major climatic shift - though the research does not directly ascribe the rise to human-caused global warming.

The research team studied NASA satellite data from 2007 to 2013 to determine the number of bushfires, to try and develop a system to forecast where they might breakout.

They estimate that in 2007 Australia had an average 3284 bushfires per week. By 2013 that had risen to 4595. The numbers were corrected downwards to account for certain fire events, such as planned burns by fire authorities.

"In particular, a major increase in bushfire frequencies has been recorded from this data analysis since 2011... indicates a major climatic shift," the study says.

The bushfire frequency numbers were determined as the researchers were endeavouring to create a model to project a week ahead where bushfires could most likely occur, and at what potential intensity.

Using a computer model, bushfire "hot spots" were determined by crunching weekly weather data such as wind speed, soil moisture, dry fuel loads and ambient air temperatures, along with numerous other inputs.

The group tested its model by looking at past conditions, then comparing where hot spots were being registered with the historical bushfire data from NASA. The model was finding hotspots where bushfires had occurred with 91 per cent accuracy.

Ritaban Dutta, a senior research scientist with CSIRO's Data61 group and an author of the study, said if the system was implemented it could help guide where best to dedicate resources in conjunction with firefighters local knowledge and other information.

Dr Dutta added that as he was not a climate scientist (rather a computer scientist and data analyst) he should not comment directly on whether global warming was behind the rise in bushfires the group had estimated.

But other scientific work has suggested that the warming climate in Australia - temperatures have risen about one degree on average since 1910 - has increased the length of the bushfire season in well populated parts of the country, along with making more frequent daily conditions of extreme fire risk.

A fact sheet released by the advocacy group, the Climate Institute, this week pointed to evidence the total yearly Forest Fire Danger Index, which measures the occurrence and severity of daily fire weather, had significantly increased at 42 per cent of sites monitored around the country since the 1970s, rising particularly rapidly in the 1990s and 2000s.

The Institute also pointed to modelling that found by 2050 the number of extreme fire days could grow in southern and eastern Australia by up to 50 per cent if greenhouse gas emissions are constrained and up to 300 per cent if they are not.

Questions about the role of climate change in creating more favourable conditions for bushfires to take hold were raised last month amid the devastating bushfires burning in parts of the Tasmanian world heritage wilderness.

urn:contentItem:5V0R-S6Y1-DXP7-13R8-00000-00State of the Climate 2018: Bureau of Meteorology and CSIRO2018-12-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:16ZLexisNexisState of the Climate 2018: Bureau of Meteorology and CSIROMichael Grose, Climate Projections Scientist, CSIRO

Australia is facing an increase in extreme heat, fire danger weather, floods and marine heatwaves, according to the latest biennial snapshot from the Bureau of Meteorology and CSIRO.

The Australian Bureau of Meteorology and CSIRO have released their fifth biennial State of the Climate report.

State of the Climate 2018 is the latest biennial snapshot of climate change in Australia. It focuses on observed long-term trends that are happening now and are likely to continue into the near future, as well as significant climate events that have occurred over the past two years. These changes are described through the latest observations from CSIRO and Bureau of Meteorology marine, atmospheric and terrestrial monitoring programs.

The report also summarises the latest climate research from Australia and around the world. This will help inform a range of economic, environmental and social risk assessments and responses by government, industry and communities.

Read more: State of the Climate 2016: Bureau of Meteorology and CSIRO

Multiple lines of evidence show the climate system changing in ways that are discernible from natural variability, and consistent with a human influence on climate. These changes are having an impact on our natural and built environment.

In particular, climate change is being felt through an increase in the frequency and severity of high-impact weather events such as heatwaves, extreme fire weather conditions, coastal inundation and marine heatwaves. These trends are projected to continue.

Some of the report's major findings are described below.

Passing major milestones

Australia's average air temperature has warmed by just over 1? since national records began in 1910. Oceans around Australia have also warmed by around 1? since 1910.

Atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide are rising globally. Emissions from the burning of fossil fuels continue to increase, and are the main contributor to the rise in CO?, with some contribution from changes in land use.

Atmospheric CO? concentrations measured at Cape Grim, Tasmania (one of three main global measuring stations, alongside Mauna Loa, Hawaii, and Nunavut, Canada), have persisted at levels above 400 parts per million (ppm) since 2016. What's more, the combined concentration of all greenhouse gases exceeded the equivalent of 500 ppm CO? in mid-2018. These milestones haven't been crossed for at least 800,000 years, and likely 2 million years.

Changes in the atmosphere and land

Australia's warming trend has led to an increase in the frequency of extreme heat events. For example, very high monthly maximum temperatures that used to occur around 2% of the time (based on the average for 1951-80) now happen about 12% of the time (2003-17).

Other elements of Australia's climate have also shown long-term changes. New analysis techniques now provide a more detailed picture of changes to fire weather through time. The annual total of daily values of the Forest Fire Danger Index is increasing over large areas of Australia. Most regions also saw an increase in the most extreme 10% of fire weather days, and fire seasons have lengthened.

Rainfall in April-October has been steadily decreasing in Western Australia's Southwest, and has decreased since the 1990s in southeast Australia. In contrast, rainfall has increased in parts of northern Australia since the 1970s.

The observed long-term reduction in rainfall across southern Australia has led to even greater reductions in streamflow. Long-term average streamflow has decreased in most regions of southern Australia, and increased in regions of northern Australia.

A warmer atmosphere can hold more moisture, and this is an important driver of the observed increase in the intensity of short-duration rainfall, sometimes linked to flash flooding. Southern Australia is projected to experience decreases in average rainfall and more time spent in drought. Meanwhile, most of the country can expect an increase in rainfall intensity.

Historically, significant weather and climate events are often the result of the combined influence of several extreme factors at once. Higher temperatures during periods of below-average rainfall, for instance, can exacerbate drought conditions. Temperature, dryness and wind come together to create dangerous bushfire conditions.

Changes in the ocean

The warming in Australia's oceans has contributed to longer and more frequent marine heatwaves - defined as periods when sea surface temperatures are much warmer than average. The world's oceans are a crucial moderator of the climate, taking up more than 90% of the extra heat in the system - most of it is absorbed by the Southern Ocean.

Sea levels continue to rise through the combined effects of warming oceans and melting ice from land-based glaciers and ice sheets. Global average sea level has risen by more than 20cm since 1880, but the rate varies from place to place. About 25% of the CO? emitted by human activity diffuses into the oceans, making them more acidic in the process.

The past two years, 2016 and 2017, have seen back-to-back bleaching events in parts of the Great Barrier Reef, linked to marine heatwave events. These changes are very likely linked to warming oceans, and primarily driven by the human influence on the climate.

Well-established scientific theory and climate model studies both show that the warming would largely not have occurred without the increase in greenhouse gas concentrations. In addition, the current increase in temperatures accords with projections made nearly 30 years ago. Warming is projected to continue into the future as the effect of past emissions continue, and more greenhouse gases are emitted. Australia is projected to experience increases in sea and air temperatures, with more hot days and marine heatwaves, and fewer cool extremes.

It takes time for the climate system to warm in response to increases in greenhouse gases, and the historical emissions over the past century have locked in some warming over the next two decades, regardless of any changes we might make to global emissions in that period. However, by the mid-21st century, higher ongoing emissions of greenhouse gases will lead to greater warming and associated impacts, and reducing emissions will lead to less warming and fewer associated impacts.

State of the Climate 2018 can be read on either the Bureau of Meteorology or CSIRO websites. The online report includes an extensive list of references and useful links.

You can also watch accompanying behind-the-scenes videos on our research on climate extremes and ocean warming.

Michael Grose receives funding from Australia's National Environmental Research Program.

Lynette Bettio does not work for, consult, own shares in or receive funding from any company or organisation that would benefit from this article, and has disclosed no relevant affiliations beyond their academic appointment.

urn:contentItem:7WG2-TTN1-2RYX-146R-00000-00Airborne attack tames wildfires2009-08-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:16ZLexisNexisFOREIGNPg. 32Airborne attack tames wildfiresNICHOLAS PAPHITIS, ATHENS

MASSIVE wildfires that destroyed homes and forests receded as an airborne attack beat back flames yesterday that at one point threatened Athens' northern suburbs.

As winds died down, Greek fire brigade spokesman Yiannis Kappakis said there were ``no significant active fronts'' left of the fire, which for days had sent a pall of smoke over the capital, plunging parts of it into a brown half-light.

Mr Kappakis said more than 1000 firefighters and soldiers would remain on duty in case the blazes revived. ``The danger of the fires flaring-up again is not yet over,'' he said.

Since Saturday, the fires have razed about 21,000ha of pine forest, olive groves, brush and farmland, according to the European Commission's European Forest Fire Information System. Greek officials say 150 homes were damaged.

Experts warned it would take generations to replace the lost forests, many of which were burnt beyond hope of natural regrowth. Thousands of people were forced to flee their homes, and elderly nuns were evacuated from the threatened convent of Saint Ephrem near the coastal town of Nea Makri - carrying the saint's relics with them.

``The flames were 30m high,'' said one of the nuns. ``Thankfully they came and rescued us.''

At least five people were treated for burns and several dozen reported breathing problems, but no injuries were serious, the Health Ministry announced.

Passing major milestones

Australia's average air temperature has warmed by just over 1? since national records began in 1910. Oceans around Australia have also warmed by around 1? since 1910.

Atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide are rising globally. Emissions from the burning of fossil fuels continue to increase, and are the main contributor to the rise in CO?, with some contribution from changes in land use.

Atmospheric CO? concentrations measured at Cape Grim, Tasmania (one of three main global measuring stations, alongside Mauna Loa, Hawaii, and Nunavut, Canada), have persisted at levels above 400 parts per million (ppm) since 2016. What's more, the combined concentration of all greenhouse gases exceeded the equivalent of 500 ppm CO? in mid-2018. These milestones haven't been crossed for at least 800,000 years, and likely 2 million years.

Changes in the atmosphere and land

Australia's warming trend has led to an increase in the frequency of extreme heat events. For example, very high monthly maximum temperatures that used to occur around 2% of the time (based on the average for 1951-80) now happen about 12% of the time (2003-17).

Other elements of Australia's climate have also shown long-term changes. New analysis techniques now provide a more detailed picture of changes to fire weather through time. The annual total of daily values of the Forest Fire Danger Index is increasing over large areas of Australia. Most regions also saw an increase in the most extreme 10% of fire weather days, and fire seasons have lengthened.

Rainfall in April-October has been steadily decreasing in Western Australia's Southwest, and has decreased since the 1990s in southeast Australia. In contrast, rainfall has increased in parts of northern Australia since the 1970s.

The observed long-term reduction in rainfall across southern Australia has led to even greater reductions in streamflow. Long-term average streamflow has decreased in most regions of southern Australia, and increased in regions of northern Australia.

A warmer atmosphere can hold more moisture, and this is an important driver of the observed increase in the intensity of short-duration rainfall, sometimes linked to flash flooding. Southern Australia is projected to experience decreases in average rainfall and more time spent in drought. Meanwhile, most of the country can expect an increase in rainfall intensity.

Historically, significant weather and climate events are often the result of the combined influence of several extreme factors at once. Higher temperatures during periods of below-average rainfall, for instance, can exacerbate drought conditions. Temperature, dryness and wind come together to create dangerous bushfire conditions.

Changes in the ocean

The warming in Australia's oceans has contributed to longer and more frequent marine heatwaves - defined as periods when sea surface temperatures are much warmer than average. The world's oceans are a crucial moderator of the climate, taking up more than 90% of the extra heat in the system - most of it is absorbed by the Southern Ocean.

Sea levels continue to rise through the combined effects of warming oceans and melting ice from land-based glaciers and ice sheets. Global average sea level has risen by more than 20cm since 1880, but the rate varies from place to place. About 25% of the CO? emitted by human activity diffuses into the oceans, making them more acidic in the process.

The past two years, 2016 and 2017, have seen back-to-back bleaching events in parts of the Great Barrier Reef, linked to marine heatwave events. These changes are very likely linked to warming oceans, and primarily driven by the human influence on the climate.

Well-established scientific theory and climate model studies both show that the warming would largely not have occurred without the increase in greenhouse gas concentrations. In addition, the current increase in temperatures accords with projections made nearly 30 years ago. Warming is projected to continue into the future as the effect of past emissions continue, and more greenhouse gases are emitted. Australia is projected to experience increases in sea and air temperatures, with more hot days and marine heatwaves, and fewer cool extremes.

It takes time for the climate system to warm in response to increases in greenhouse gases, and the historical emissions over the past century have locked in some warming over the next two decades, regardless of any changes we might make to global emissions in that period. However, by the mid-21st century, higher ongoing emissions of greenhouse gases will lead to greater warming and associated impacts, and reducing emissions will lead to less warming and fewer associated impacts.

State of the Climate 2018 can be read on either the Bureau of Meteorology or CSIRO websites. The online report includes an extensive list of references and useful links.

You can also watch accompanying behind-the-scenes videos on our research on climate extremes and ocean warming.

urn:contentItem:4V0J-3GN0-TXDB-G060-00000-00CSIRO unveils bushfire wind tunnel2008-11-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:16ZLexisNexisCSIRO unveils bushfire wind tunnel

The CSIRO has unveiled a 25-metre long bushfire wind tunnel to improve firefighting capabilities.

The Pyrotron tunnel in Canberra will allow for researchers to conduct experiments to increase understanding of bushfire behaviour.

Over the past 40 years bushfires in Australia have destroyed more than 4 ,500 houses.

NSW Rural Fire Service Assistant Commissioner Mark Crosweller says the Pyrotron is going to help learn more about bushfires.

"What it allows us to do is literally to get right up and close to the fuel that is burning in a forest fire," he said.

"All of the experimentation we've done over many years, we've had to stand well back to observe the fire from some distance.

"This allows us to approach the fuels within about 300, 400 millimetres and actively observe what the fire is doing."

Assistant Commissioner Crosweller says the experiments will build on existing bushfire behaviour research.

"The science of bushfire is still a very much evolving science, this will certainly fill in a lot of gaps," he said.

"Fighting fire is as much an art as it is a science, so the art of firefighting and the techniques firefighters use will be greatly enhanced by the knowledge that apparatuses such as this produce."

urn:contentItem:5H2X-KXC1-DXMH-10JP-00000-00Australian company investigated over Indonesian fires2015-10-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:16ZLexisNexisAustralian company investigated over Indonesian firesJewel Topsfield

Indonesia rules out evacuations in forest fire areas   Troops battle fires as thousands fall ill in Malaysia, Singapore   Singapore and Malaysia urged to share responsibility for fires   Asian haze set to become worst on record

Jakarta: An Australian company is reportedly being investigated by Indonesian police over a fire on a palm oil plantation in Borneo as the republic tries to crack down on companies responsible for the haze choking the region.

Kayung Agro Lestari, which has a palm oil plantation in Ketapang regency in West Kalimantan, is one of 42 companies being investigated over the forest fires.

The slash-and-burn technique of land clearing used by some palm oil and timber plantations is commonly blamed for starting the fires, which have created dangerous levels of air pollution in parts of Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore.

The fires dog the region every year but have been exacerbated this year by El Nino and protracted drought in parts of Indonesia.

Malaysia has ordered all schools to close for two days because of the thick smog and the first night of finals at swimming's World Cup in Singapore was cancelled on Saturday.

Indonesian police told reporters that as of October 1 they were investigating 232 cases of forest and plantation fires. Forty-two cases involve corporations, including two foreign investment companies - Kayung Agro Lestari (PT KAL) from Australia and PT ASP from China.

In a statement late last month, Kayung Agro Lestari said that as of September 22, 356 hectares on its 17,998 concession had caught fire. "These fires were caused by windborne sparks from fires outside our plantation area," it said. "All of these fires have been put out by our team."

The statement said Kalimantan was facing an extremely dry climate and high winds. "Together they make the plantation vulnerable to outbreaks of fire, especially from wind-borne sparks originating in fires outside our plantation."

Kayung Agro Lestari said it was in daily coordination with the police and regional disaster management in fighting the fires and investigating their causes.

"The most serious outbreak PT KAL has witnessed was a fire affecting a large area of land just beside our plantation. Our team has worked together with the local authorities and communities to contain the fire. We also recorded that five orangutan fled from the fire and moved into our conservation area. As far as we can determine they are unharmed."

Rising global demand for palm oil, which is widely used in food and cosmetics, has led to the clearing of forests in Indonesian national parks, high levels of greenhouse gas emissions and the destruction of the habitat of endangered species including the Sumatran orangutan and tiger.

Kayung Agro Lestari is a subsidiary of PT Austindo Nusantara Jaya Agri, which is a member of the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil.

Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil certification is an assurance to buyers of palm oil products that the standard of production is sustainable

urn:contentItem:59J1-6371-JD3N-50RC-00000-00Love to be by the seaside in Mallorca2013-10-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:16ZLexisNexisTRAVELPg. 55Love to be by the seaside in MallorcaBRIGITTE KRAMER

THE Serra de Tramuntana mountain range forms the northern backbone of the Spanish island of Mallorca

and is characterised by rugged peaks rising up close to the sea, fertile slopes, pine forests and a dense network of streams.

Thanks to its geography, many small seaside villages are almost hidden from the outside world with the inhabitants often continuing to make a living from fishing and crops planted on the ``marjades'' or stepped slopes, which lead down to the Mediterranean Sea.

One such village is Banyalbufar, on Mallorca's rugged western coast. The regional Ma-10 road runs through the entire 90km length of the Serra de Tramuntana from Andratx to Pollenca. The first few kilometres pass through an area that bears the fresh scars of the devastating forest fire that ripped through the area in August.

The island's countless picturesque bays and coves are particularly popular during autumn, thanks in part to mild-water temperatures ranging between 20 and 24 degrees Celsius.

Almost all tourists in the European autumn congregate around the small pebble beaches at Estellencs, Banyalbufar, Port des Canonge or Estaca, while daily life on the island slowly returns to normal after the long summer season.

As a result, hikers have the Serra de Tramuntana virtually to themselves during autumn. The mountain range offers almost everything nature lovers could ask for within its 1100 square kilometres - so much so that the region's peaks, valleys and coves were listed as Unesco sites in 2011.

Time seems to stand still in Banyalbufar, where clay-coloured houses fill the narrow space along the jagged coastline between sea and mountains. One of the island's oldest trading tracks, which dates back to the early 15th century, ends here and to this day still runs eight kilometres from the village church at Esporles over the Coll d'es Pi.

Further northeast along the coast near Port de Valldemossa lies S'Estaca, which can be reached via a footpath that winds along the coastline and passes age-old olive trees and imposing country estates.

The Estaca bay also offers great bathing opportunities although visitors should bring their own provisions to the more isolated spots and make the journey during the week when the locals are at work, as these secluded coves are particularly popular with Mallorcans.

urn:contentItem:5P2X-9951-JBJ7-N3TC-00000-00Return of 'big dry' points to active, early fire season2017-07-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:16ZLexisNexisReturn of 'big dry' points to active, early fire seasonPeter Hannam

Weather patterns delivering an exceptionally dry winter across south-eastern Australia show little sign of breaking up.

Weather patterns delivering an exceptionally dry winter across south-eastern Australia show little sign of breaking up, heightening concerns the coming fire season will be an early and active one.

Fire authorities won't formally release predictions for spring and summer until September. Wet periods in autumn, though, curbed hazard-reduction burning to half the year-earlier totals in NSW and curtailed it in Victoria.

"The next four to six weeks are going to be very important," said Ben Shepherd, an inspector and head of media at the NSW Rural Fire Service.

"Many of the agencies are looking for that opportunity to get out there and start those [hazard-reduction] burns again in earnest" before conditions turn too windy and warm, he said.

Authorities stress a significant rain event could yet push fire risks for the coming season back towards more typical levels but note that there is little sign of such a development.

High-pressure systems have dominated southern Australia, nudging rain-bearing systems south of the continent.

Saturday offered a clear illustration of the set-up. The bureau predicted almost the entire mainland of Australia would be dry. (See chart below.)

The skies have been clear with an unusually wide diurnal temperature range over many regions. Nights were marked by heavy frosts or cold making way for milder than average days.

Big dry

Barring some unexpected instability, July will join last month as among Australia's driest.

Nationally, last month was the second-driest June since standard data began in 1910 with rainfall barely a third of average, the Bureau of Meteorology said.

Victoria had its driest June, NSW was the driest in 15 years and the Murray Darling Basin posted its lowest rainfall totals since 1986.

"It very much seems to be centring on the border between Victoria and NSW," Richard Thornton, chief executive of the Bushfire and Natural Hazards Cooperative Research Centre, said of the rainfall deficits.

Winter-to-date rainfall levels have been "very much below average" for most of southern Australia, bureau data shows. (See chart below).

'Back foot'

Fire authorities are keen to take advantage of the cool and dry conditions to ramp up controlled burns before windy and warmer days make such activities more risky.

Cyclone Debbie's aftermath brought heavy rain to much of the east coast in April, reducing opportunities for hazard-reduction burning. "That really put us on the back foot," Mr Shepherd said.

In a typical year about 56 per cent of controlled burns in NSW are conducted in autumn and 23 per cent in spring.

During autumn, the RFS treated 93,116 hectares to protect 23,171 properties. By area, the tally was less than half the previous autumn's 191,684 hectares involving 27,867 properties.

Forest Fire Management Victoria places less emphasis on the size of area burnt in its hazard-reduction program than the risk. During the year to June 2017, FFMVic crews conducted 351 burns over 113,172 hectares statewide.

"The wet winter and spring conditions proved difficult, however our prioritisation of burns based on risk has resulted in the statewide risk being maintained at 2015-16 levels," said Stephanie Rotarangi, the agency's chief fire officer.

Longer-term trends

The key influence behind this year's relatively dry winter is far to the south. A positive phase in the so-called Southern Annular Mode marks a poleward contraction of the westerly winds belt towards Antarctica.

As the bureau notes, such a phase marked the Millennium drought during the "big dry" from 1997-2010. High-pressure systems that would normally sit further north track across more southerly parts of Australia blocking rain-bearing cold fronts.

In June, average mean sea level pressure readings were at record highs for many parts of southern Australia, including all but one site in South Australia and all but three in Victoria.

As the bureau noted: "Mean sea level pressure over southern Australia has been increasing in winter over recent decades. This pattern is consistent with future climate change projections for the Australian region."

Dr Thornton of the Hazards CRC said that along with trends towards drier winters for southern Australia, warmer-than-average temperatures during July to September are also the new norm.

"It's almost locked in to have above-average temperatures from climate change," he said.

The bureau will update its three-month outlook this coming week. At its most recent projection, the agency said odds were strongly pointing to a drier-than-usual July to September for much of the south of the country. (See chart below.)

urn:contentItem:5993-0T41-JCM0-6215-00000-00Tumut Shire Council leads a push for a new approach for out of control blackberries through more strategic management2013-09-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:16ZLexisNexisTumut Shire Council leads a push for a new approach for out of control blackberries through more strategic management

The blackberry problem on the South West Slopes is so bad authorities have declared that the weed will never be controlled, let alone eradicated.

The Tumut Shire Council hosted a Blackberry Forum this week attended by neighbouring councils and various state government agencies.

The Council's Director of Environment, Paul Mullins says local growing conditions are ideal for blackberries and steep topography makes control efforts almost impossible.

"It's very costly to control blackberries by the conventional means, either herbicide spraying or mechanical control - slashing it out and burning it," he said.

"The reality is it's almost become too big a problem to control it totally. In fact that acknowledgement was made at the forum."

Mr Mullins says a new approach is needed to stop money being wasted in uncoordinated control efforts.

He says a working party has been formed which will develop a long term control strategy for the southwest slopes.

Mr Mullins says despite all the efforts to control blackberries, the area affected by the brambles continues to grow, especially in state forests and national parks.

"They, like council and private landowners have got limited resources and blackberries are basically taking a major hold. Our concern was that all of the effort that's been put into it, if you go back to these areas two or three years later, you're back to where you started"

"We're just wasting a lot of time and effort. So we want to look at how we can do things better," he said.

Thick stands of blackberries posed a fire risk in a state forest fire near Tumut in 2006.

Mr Mullins says the weed is a haven to pest animals and can cut farm output significantly.

"National Parks and the Forestry Corporation do put a lot of effort in to controlling the blackberries within their trail networks because they need to keep the fire trails accessible. But just doing that is taking up most of their resources, which means they don't then have the resources to do control work beyond. The environmental impacts, they take productive land out of production, costing the farming community many millions of dollars in lost productivity."

urn:contentItem:5FHG-7HC1-JD34-V261-00000-00my place2015-03-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2my place

For Karen Huntly, a trip to her favourite bookshop is a cause for celebration.

When I step through the door, my shoulders relax, my jaw loosens and I smile; at least on the inside. I'm in the company of murderers, neurotics and the melancholy and feel very much at home.

Throw in a few satirists, sailors and a hobbit or two and there's no place I'd rather be.

The mere idea of a morning trawling a crowded and faux-marbled mall in search of shoes or a dress will see me curl up into a fetal position and call for mercy, alcohol or both.

But the promise of a trip to a bookshop is cause for celebration.

Near to where I work is Hill of Content, which is now more than 90 years old and, when I'm having a bad day, it is to this old lady that I head for comfort.

Among the spines facing out from the floor to ceiling shelves I recognise the names of some old friends and a couple I'd rather forget. Several tables fill much of the central carpeted space, on top of which, face-up, lie novels and memoirs, cookbooks and historical biographies; newcomers waiting to be introduced.

I know where to go to find Barry Maitland, Peter Temple and Agatha Christie, and can just as easily lay my hands on Thomas Hardy and Anthony Trollope.

France, Italy and the Galapagos Islands are an arm's length away and in the far back corner the folk of the Faraway Tree beckon.

E-books and iBooks have their place but it's not my place.

What is your favourite place? Send in your 250-word piece to sunday@theage.com.au You can even attach a photograph.

MEANWHILE, WHAT'S HAPPENING IN ... INDIANA

Local authorities in Muncie are flat out counting potholes in local streets following the end of winter. More than 2000 potholes have been counted so far. Meanwhile, a meth lab has been found operating out of a Walmart restroom.

urn:contentItem:801V-WH70-YBDY-R1MY-00000-00Ready to face fire risk2010-07-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Ready to face fire riskServices | Peter Strachan

EMERALD'S new CFA station will give the district state-of-the-art bushfire protection during the fire season.

The station in Emerald-Monbulk Rd replaces a 1940s building in Main Rd and will be a divisional

command centre in disastrous

wildfires.

Brigade captain Paul Yandle said the old building was too small to house trucks and equipment and no longer met occupational health and safety regulations.

``We had crews dressing from hooks beside trucks that were likely to move and inadequate space for meetings,'' Mr Yandle said. ``We had simply outgrown it and it no longer met the demands we faced in situations like Black Saturday.''

The new building has advanced communication equipment, a modern turnout room and collects rainwater to meet all training needs for its 40 active firefighters.

``We are far better placed to face summer fire risks than we were, but there is a real need not to become complacent,'' he said.

``Any summer can produce a holocaust and it is vital everybody has a fire plan and remains vigilant on days of high fire risk.''

He said Emerald residents had a serious fright when faced with a 4ha grass and forest fire in January.

``We were lucky,'' Mr Yandle said. ``It came close to the north of the town, but was controlled before it threatened housing. It alerted a lot of people to the risk we face here.''

Would you stay or go if threatened by a bushfire near your home? Tell us at pakenhamleader.com.au

urn:contentItem:801D-KTM1-2RYX-150R-00000-00Bailey's European study trip2010-07-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8Bailey's European study tripTravel | Alex Munro

A STUDY tour of Europe to investigate the latest fire detection technologies in the wake of Black Saturday cost taxpayers $22,000.

McEwen federal Liberal MP Fran Bailey took the study tour in 2009, visiting Portugal, Belgium, Germany, the UK and Singapore to evaluate bushfire detection and prevention techniques.

The tour's $22,156 cost was revealed in a parliamentary expenditure report in June.

Mrs Bailey said it had been important to study the state-of-the-art early fire detection technology being successfully used in Europe, after the devastating fires of February, 2009.

``As a result of my study trip, I was able to convince the then Prime Minister and the Attorney-General to fund and authorise trials over summer in Australia,'' she said.

``Trials took place in Victoria and NSW and the results are now being evaluated by CSIRO. Better early fire detection was one of four key areas I identified following Black Saturday.

``Another was fuel reduction programs and on behalf of our local communities, I am continuing to advocate for a model similar to the one used in the Sintra region of Portugal.''

Casey federal Liberal MP Tony Smith spent nothing on overseas trips in the July to December 2009 period.

Mrs Bailey told residents at a community meeting in March (Leader, March 8) that the Yarra Ranges would be a priority area for the bushfire-detection sensors if the Federal Government backed them.

The high-tech sensors can tell the difference between a forest fire, dust, cloud or mist.

urn:contentItem:4PFF-CVH0-TX52-J4G0-00000-00Hundreds flee Athens fire2007-08-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 21

AFP

Hundreds flee Athens fire

ATHENS -- Hundreds of Greek firemen battled through the night to bring a forest fire threatening Athens under control yesterday after it destroyed dozens of houses and forced hundreds to flee.

More than 300 firemen backed by three helicopters were still fighting the fire on Mount Pentelikon, north of the capital, emergency services said yesterday.

More than 10 houses in the wealthy district were destroyed and firemen evacuated two clinics as winds of more than 80km/h pushed flames toward them.

In Melissia, 20km from central Athens, 130 patients were moved from a clinic.

One firefighter was injured in the operation and one emergency vehicle was burned. A dark cloud of smoke covered much of northern Athens.

Answering criticism that fire services had reacted too slowly, police spokesman Evangelos Falaras said water-bombing planes had been hampered by smoke and violent winds.

The fire services said the forest blaze may have been deliberately started.

Summer fires are regularly blamed on property speculators who burn forests in protected zones so they can then build on the land, even illegally.

The fire ravaged a pine grove reforested after fires in 1995 and 1998 destroyed thousands of hectares of trees.

urn:contentItem:5K8M-RMV1-JD3N-53VW-00000-00Blake dries the tears2016-07-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:44:16ZLexisNexisHITPg. 34Blake dries the tearsKathy McCabe

The singer has put his relationship pain behind him, writes Kathy McCabe

CELEBRATED British electronic pop experimental-ist and vocal magician James Blake's much-anticipated third album arrived unexpectedly in May after a few false starts. It appeared guerilla-style but Blake says it was well overdue.

"More than (surprising everyone) I enjoyed the chunks of anxiety that dropped off me and the feeling of closure after three years of my life. That was a really big moment for me," he says. "Making a record can be emotionally very draining." Blake became one of the most celebrated artists in the world with the genre-bending 2013 album Overgrown, his own work revered as a bold exploration of a new electronic frontier and sought after by Kanye West, Drake, Bon Iver, Frank Ocean and Beyonce for his evocative voice and its trademark melancholy.

Touring off the back of an album about a relationship breakdown as you are being declared a Next Big Thing and feted by the pop elite messed with his head.

While he speaks seriously of pruning distractions and demons in order to be in the creative headspace needed to finish new album The Colour in Anything, Blake is upbeat and energised about taking the new songs on the road.

The 27-year-old singer, pianist and songwriter debuted new songs including Modern Soul, Radio Silence and Timeless at a Los Angeles theatre show in late May to pindrop silence and rapturous applause.

He says he feels more confident about his live show now and admits to vampirically feeding off the energy of his audience, whether they may be enraptured or moved to tears. Somehow he manages to keep his own eyes dry when pouring out his oh-so-sad songs.

"Some shows really take it out of me because they are so emotional and this is probably the most emotional, regarding the lyrics," he says. "It's hard sometimes (keeping it together) and luckily I am with the person I wrote a lot of the songs about so this is cathartic and beautiful.

"I was no longer with the person I wrote the last record about a month into the tour and it was really hard, it was a mess.

"You are dealing with your purest emotional capacities pretty much every night. Sometimes it feels weird to have chosen that as a job." You would imagine he and Justin Vernon, who turned his heartache into the treasured debut Bon Iver record For Emma, Forever Ago, have had plenty to talk about during their collaborations in recent years.

Vernon guests on the new song I Need a Forest Fire and Blake admits the two mates have compared notes on negotiating the vagaries of fame and those girlfriend ghosts. "He is such an amazing person who has been through it all and is a very sensitive, kind individual," Blake says. "He's a good person to talk to, isn't he?" Blake cracks up when asked if he has taken advantage of his success to improve the quality of his backstage rider. While he may be all melancholy in music, the sad-song guy has a finely-honed sense of the ridiculous.

"The rider no longer features tissues for crying after the show; it's just better alcohol," he says.

Like all young touring artists, he decided to include an absurd request on his list of backstage requirements on his last tour and when his inclusion of "badger" became public, fans delivered. "Almost every city we visited, we were gifted badgers, not real ones, of course," he says. "There were inflatable badgers, keyrings, the surprise badger could be anything. It was our way of assuring promoters we weren't going to ask for a week's supply of socks or a puppy."SEE: JAMES BLAKE, THEBARTON THEATRE, JULY 28. BOOK AT TICKETMASTER
